sp.p: Know. I have Five Hundred Pounds a Year.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: And the Devil and all of Expectations from an Old Woman.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: And this Youth, and little Beauty to lay out in love. Pulls off her Mask.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Tereſia! the lovely Maid deſign'd for my Mother, now, what a Dog am I? that gives me the greater Guſt to her, and wou'd fain Cuckold my Father. [Talks to her aſide.

div.stage: [Mirtilla ſeems to faint.]

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: My Lady faints — help, help.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Only the beat Oppreſſes me— but let it not diſturb the Company. I'll take the Air a little, and return Goes cut with Manage.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Is this deſign'd, or real— perhaps ſhe is retir'd for me— M • s. Manage—

div.stage: Manage Re-enters, he pulls her by the ſleeve.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ha! Monſieur Lejere! what ſhall I feign to put him off withal. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Why doſt thou ſtart? How do's my dear Mirtilla?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Repoſing, Sir, a while, but anon I'll wait on her for your admittance.

div.stage: Prince Frederick puts on Welborn's Cloak, goes out, and Welborn enters into the Company dreſs'd like the Prince.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Ha, ſhe ſpoke in paſſing by that gay thing — What means it, but I'll trace the Myſtery.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: The young People are Lazy, and here's nothing but gaping and peeping in one anothers Vizards; come, Madam, let you and I ſhame 'em into Action. (Sir Rowland, and Lady Youthly, Dance.)

div.stage: After the Dance, enter Olivia with a Letter. Olivia gives Welborn the Letter.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Ha! what's this, Sir, a Challenge?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: A Soft One, Sir.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: A Billet — whoe'er the Lady be. (Reads.) She merits ſomething for but believing I am worth her Mirth.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I know not, Sir, how great a Jeſt you may make of it; but I aſſure you the Lady is in earneſt, and if you be at leiſure to hear Reaſon from her.—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Fair and ſoftly, my Dear Love Meſſenger, I am for no haſty Bargains; not but I ſhou'd be glad to hear Reaſon from any of the Sex — But I have been ſo damnably Jilted — Is ſhe of Quality?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Then I'll not hear any thing from her; they are troubleſome, and inſolent; and if ſhe have a Husband, to hide her Intriegues ſhe has recourſe to all the little Arts and Cunnings of her Sex; and ſhe that jilts her Husband, will her Lover.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: She is not troubled with a Husband, Sir.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: What, ſhe's parted from the Fool; then ſhe's Expenſive, and for want of Alimony, jilts all the believing Block-heads that ſhe meets with.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: But this is a Maid, Sir.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Worſe ſtill! At every turn ſhe's raving on her Honour; then if ſhe have a Kinſman, or a Brother, I muſt be Challeng'd.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Sir, you miſtake, my Lady is for Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: You have not forſworn it, I hope.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Not ſo— but—

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: If a Lady, Young and Handſom, and Ten Thouſand Pounds—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Nay, I am not poſitive —

div.stage: Enter Sir Morgan, and Sir Merlin, Drunk, Singing.
Sir Morg. and Sir Merl. Singing.
div.l: Wiſe Coxcombs be damn'd, here's a Health to the Man,
That ſince Life is but ſhort, lives as long as he can.

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: Where is my Lady Mirtilla, Rogues?

sp.speaker: Sir Merl.
sp.p: And my Miſtreſs, Raſcals? For we are reſolv'd to ſhew our ſelves in Triumph to our Wives and Miſtreſſes.

sp.speaker: L. You.
sp.p: Your Miſtreſs, Sir Merlin? miſtake not your Mark,

sp.speaker: Sir Merl.
sp.p: Ha! Art thou there, old Cathedral? Why thou look'ſt as magnificently as Old Queen Beſs in the Weſtminſter-Cupboard.
Lookee as de ſee, when Adam wore a Beard, ſhe was in her Prime, or ſo, de ſee. (Sings.)

sp.speaker: L. You.
sp.p: Sir, you are a ſaucy Jack, and your Father ſhall correct you.

sp.speaker: Sir Merl.
sp.p: My Father! my Father's an old Toſt, de ſee; and I hope to ſee him hang'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Here's a Heathen-Chriſtian! ſee his Father hang'd!

sp.speaker: Sir Merl.
sp.p: Ay hang'd, and all the old Fathers in Chriſtendom. Why, what-a-Pox ſhou'd Fathers trouble the World for? When I come to Reign in Parliament, I will enact it Felony, for any Father to have ſo little Grace to live, that has a Son at Years of Diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: A damn'd Rogue, I'll diſinherit him immediately.

sp.speaker: L. Blun.
sp.p: Is it ſo great a Crime, Brother, for a Gentleman to be Drunk?

sp.speaker: Sir Merl.
sp.p: You Lye like a Son of a Whore — I have been drinking Confuſion to all the Fathers and Husbands in England.

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: How, Sir, Confuſion to Husbands! Lookee de ſee, Sir, ſwallow me that Word, or I'll make you depoſite all the conjugal Wine you have drunk.

sp.speaker: Sir Merl.
sp.p: I depoſite all your Wine! Sirrah, you're a Blunderbuſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: Sirrah! you are a diminitive Bully.

sp.speaker: Sir Merl.
sp.p: Sirrah! you're the Whore of Babylon, and I defie you.

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: Lookee de ſee, I ſcorn to draw upon a drunken Man, or ſo, I being ſober; but I boldly challenge you into the Cellar, where thou ſhalt drink till thou renounce thy Character, or talk Treaſon enough to hang thee, and that's fair and civil.

sp.speaker: Sir Merl.
sp.p: Agreed; and when I'm drunk enough to raviſh, I'll Cuckold my old Dad, and fight him for his Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: I have no Patience; I'll kill the Dog, becauſe I'll have the Law on my ſide— Come on, Sir. (Draws, the Ladies run out.)

div.stage: (Sir Merlin draws) George runs in and parts 'em.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Villain! Raſcal! What, draw upon thy Father!

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, who are you? that I may thank you for my Life.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: One, Sir, whoſe Duty 'twas. (Pulls off his Viſard.)

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: What, my dear George! — I'll go and cut off the Inta • of my Eſtate preſently, and thou ſhalt have it all, Boy, thou ſhalt—

div.stage: Exeunt all but George.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Fortune is ſtill my Friend! Had but Mirtilla been ſo! I wonder that ſhe ſends not to me! My Love's impatient, and I cannot wait — while the dull Sot is boozing with his Brother-Fools in the Cellar. I'll ſoftly to the Chamber of my Love — Perhaps ſhe waits me there— Exit.

div.head: SCENE the Second.
div.stage: A Chamber, and Alcove, diſcovers Mirtilla, and Prince Frederick.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Oh! I am raviſh'd with exceſs of Joy.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Enough, my charming Prince! Oh, you have ſaid enough!

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Never, my Mirtilla!

The Sun that views the World, nor the bright Moon, that favours Lover • Stealths, ſhall ever ſee that Hour. Vaſt, as thy Beauties, are my young Deſires; and every new Poſſeſſion kindles new Flames, ſoft as thy Eyes, ſoft as thy render Touches, and, e'er the Pantings of my Heart are laid, new Tranſports, from new Wiſhes, dance about it, and ſtill remains in Love's Harmonious Order. (Kiſſes and Embraces her.)

div.stage: Enter George, ſoftly.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: This Houſe I know, and this ſhould be her Bed-Chamber, becauſe the Beſt; and yet methought I heard another Voice — but I may be miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I faint with Pleaſure of each tender Claſp: I ſigh, and languiſh, gazing on thy Lyes; and dye upon thy Lips, with every Kiſs!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Surely I know that Voice! Torments, and Hell!— but 'tis impoſſible? (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Oh! ſatisfie my Doubt, my trembling Doubt! Am I belov'd? Have I about me ought engaging to Thee, Charmer of my Soul?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: It is the Prince. (Aſide)

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ah, Prince! Can you ſuch needleſs Queſtions ask, after the Sacrifice which I have made.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Hell take thee for that Falſhood. (Draws.)

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Think not the mighty Preſent of your Jewels, enough to purchaſe Provinces, has bought one ſingle Sigh, or Wiſh: No, my dear Prince, you owe 'em all to Love, and your own Charms.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Oh damn'd, diſſembling Jilt! (Aſide)

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: No more, no more, my Soul's oppreſt with Joy: let me unload it in thy tender Arms, and ſigh it out into thy raviſhing Boſom.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Death, and Damnation! —
I ſhall forget his Quality, and Virtue, forget he was my Friend or ſav'd this Life; and like a River, ſwell'd with angry Tydes, o'erflow thoſe Banks that made the Stre • m ſo gay.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Who's there?— I heard a Voice— Manage?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Yes. (Softly.)

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Approach thou Confident of all my Joys; approach, and be Rewarded— (Prince takes his J • wel from his Hat.)

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Yes, for my excellent Bawding — By Heav'n I dar not touch his Princely Perſon.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Where art thou? take this Jewel, and retire. (Gropes for his Hand, gives it him.)

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Ev'n my Misfortunes have a ſort of Luck; but I'll withdraw, for fear this Devil about me, ſhou'd raiſe my too raſh Hand againſt his Life.

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Come, my eternal Pleaſure— each Moment of the happy Lover's Hour, is worth an Age of dull, and common Life Exeunt into the Alcove, the Scene ſhuts.

div.head: SCENE the Third. A Garden, by Night Still.
div.stage: Enter George with his Sword in his Hand, as before.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p:
Why do I vainly call for Vengeance down, and have it in my Hand? — By • eav'n, I'll back — Whether? To kill a Woman, a young perjur'd Woman! — Oh, ye falſe Fair Ones! ſhou'd we do you Juſtice,
A univerſal Ruin wou'd enſue; Not One wou'd live to ſtock the World anew. Who is't among ye All, ye Fair Deceivers, ye Charming Miſchiefs to the Noble Race, can ſwear ſhe's Innocent, without Damnation? No, no, go on — be falſe— be fickle ſtill: You act but Nature— but my faithleſs Friend — where I repoſe the Secrets of my Soul — except this one— Alas! he knew not this: — Why do I blame him then?

div.stage: Enter Olivia, dreſs'd as before.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Fire! Fire! Fire!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Olivia's Voice! — Ha! what art thou? Thy Voice ſhou'd be Olivia's, but thy Shape— And yet a Woman is all o'er Diſguiſe.

div.stage: Enter Lady Blunder in her Night-Gown.

sp.speaker: L. Blun.
sp.p: Fire! Fire! Fire! My Son, my dear Sir Morgan.

div.stage: Enter Sir Rowland, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: A Pox on your Son, and mine to boot; they have ſet all the Sack-Butts a Flaming in the Cellar, thence the Miſchief began. Timothy, Roger, Jeffrey, my Money-Trunks, ye Rogues! my Money-Trunks!

sp.speaker: L. Blun.
sp.p: My Son, good Roger! my own Sir Moggy!

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: The Ten thouſand Pounds, ye Raſcal, in the Iron Trunk, that was to be paid Mr. Welborn for Olivia's Portion. Exit.

sp.speaker: L. Blun.
sp.p: Oh my Son! my Son!— Run to the Parſon, Sam, and let him ſend the Church-Buckets. Oh, ſome help! ſome help!

div.stage: Enter Manage.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh, Heavens! my Lady Mirtilla's Chamber's all on Flame.

div.stage: Enter Britton.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Ha,— the Prince! I had forgot his Danger.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ah! look up, and ſee how it burns!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Britton, a Million for a Ladder!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Bleſſing on you, Sir, if you dare venture through the Houſe, there lies one in the Fore Garden.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: The Paſſage is on fire, Sir, you cannot go.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Revenge is vaniſh'd, and Love takes its place: Soft Love, and mightier Friendſhip ſeizes all. I'll ſave him, tho' I periſh in the Attempt. Runs out, Britton after him.

div.stage: Enter, at another Door, Sir Rowland.

sp.speaker: L. Blun.
sp.p: A Thouſand Pound for him that ſaves Sir Morgan.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: And, de ye hear, let my Rogue lie; I'd rather he ſhould be burnt, than hang'd on Tyburn Road, for murthering his Father.— But where's Boy George?

div.stage: Enter Men with Trunks.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Safe, Sir, I hope; he was not in the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: So, ſo, away with theſe Trunks to my Lady Youthly's in Southampton-Square, and tell her we muſt trouble her to Night. Come, Siſter, let's away. Exeunt Lady Blunder, and Sir Rowland,

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Frederick, and Mirtilla, appear at the Window, the Flame behind 'em.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Help, help, and ſave Mirtilla! Ask any Price, my Life, my Fortune! All!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Oh, Heav'ns! the Flame purſues us as we fly.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: No help! Oh Gods, I ſhall prevent the Flame, and periſh by my Fears to ſee you dye!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Alas! Sir, you with eaſe may ſave your Life! This Window you may leap, but I want Courage.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: No, my Mirtilla, if it be thy Fate, I'll graſp thee, ev'n in Flames, and dye with thee.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: We dye! we dye! the Flame takes hold of us!

div.stage: Enter George with a Ladder, and puts it to the Window.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Ha! ſome pitying God takes Care of us. Haſt, haſt, my Charmer; Heav'n has ſent us Aid. Puts her on the Ladder, ſhe deſcends into George's Arms; after her, the Prince. George puts her into Manage's Arms, ſhe faints; he runs up to receive the Prince.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Lejere! dear Man of Luck — Some happy Star reign'd at thy glorious Birth; every thing is proſperous thou eſpouſeſt. — How fares my Love, the Treaſure of my Soul?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Only fainting with the Fright, but ſhe recovers.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: My Chair there, quickly, that waits for me.— (Enter Chair; he puts her, and Manage into it.)
Carry 'em to Mr. Welborn's, to my Lodgings there, and then return to me; for I am wondrous faint, and cannot walk.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Ha! by my Life, my Man!

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: But if I might impoſe ſo much Lejere upon thy Friendſhip, I beg thou wouldſt ſee her ſafely carry'd to my Lodgings at Welborn's.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You ſhall Command me, Sir. Exeunt Chair, George, and Britton.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: You ſeem not well, Sir; pray repoſe upon my Arm a while.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir, indeed I am not well.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Methinks I find a Pleaſure but in touching him — Wou'd I • ou'd ſee his Face by all this fatal Light.

div.stage: Enter Conſtable and Watch.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: So, ſo, the Fire abates, the Engines play'd rarely; and we have Ten Guinea's here, Neighbours, to watch about the Houſe; for where there's Fire, there's Rogues — Hum, who have we here?— How now, Mr.— Hum, what have you got under your Arm there, ha? Take away this Box of Jewels.
sp.stage: (Sir Morgan, and Sir Merlin, creeping out of the Cellar Window.)
sp.p: Ha, who have we here creeping out of the Cellar-Window? more Rogues!

sp.speaker: Sir Mer.
sp.p:
Sirrah! you're a Bawd, Sirrah! and for a Teſter will wink at the Vices of the Nation, Sirrah! Call Men of the beſt Quality, Rogues!
that have ſtood for Knights of the Shire, and made the Mobile drunk Sirrah!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: We cry you Mercy, Sir, we did not know your Worſhips.

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: Lookee de ſee, here's a Crown for you; carry us to the next Tavern, and we'll make thee, and all thy Mirmidons, as drunk as a Boat in a Storm.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Sir, I find you have Intereſt with theſe Arbitrary Tyrants of the Pariſh; Pray will you bail me, and this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Sir Merl.
sp.p: What, Endimion! my Lady Mirtilla's Page? He lent me Money to Night at the Baſſet-Table; I'll be bound Hand and Foot for him, Mr. Conſtable, and gad we'll all to the Tavern, and drink up the Sun, Boys.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Yonder Gentleman too has receiv'd ſome Hurt by the Fire, and muſt go Home, Sir; but you muſt reſtore him the Box, Mr. Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: Ay, ay, lookee de ſee, return the Gentleman all; they're Gentlemen, and our intimate Friends, de ſee. Exeunt Prince, and Olivia.

div.stage: Enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Stand: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: Philip — Lookee de ſee, he ſhall along with us to the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir Morgan, I came to ſeek you: Your Lady Mother ſent me back on purpoſe; ſhe has ſpoil'd her Beauty with crying for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: And waſh'd off all her Paint?— Or ſo de ſee! Gad ſa' me, Philip, this is ill Luck. Come let us go drink down Sorrow.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Being ſent of ſuch an Errand, as your Safety, Sir, I dare not ſtay and drink now, before I've ſatisfy'd your Mother.

sp.speaker: Sir Mer.
sp.p: Not drink! I charge you, in the King's Name, Mr. Conſtable, bring him along. (The Conſtable and Watch ſeize him.)
sp.l: Wiſe Coxcombs be damn'd, here's a Health to the Man,
That ſince Life is but ſhort, lives as long as he can.

div.head: SCENE the Firſt. The Prince's Lodgings.
div.stage: Enter Page with Lights. Sets 'em on the Table, Exit.
Enter Mirtilla led by Mrs. Manage.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: HA! where am I, Manage?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Heav'n be thank'd, Madam, at the Prince's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What happy Star conducted us, and ſav'd us from the Fury of the Flames?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Thoſe whoſe Influence are always Gracious to your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: But where's the Prince? Where's my Illuſtrious Lover?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Waiting the Return of the Chair, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: But my Endimion!— Is Endimion ſafe?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Madam, he is: I ſaw him in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Then periſh all the reſt — Go ſend to ſearch him out, and let him inſtantly be brought to me. — Ha — Lejere!

div.stage: Enter George.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Bawd ſtand aſide — and do your Office yonder — [Puts away Manage. Why are you frighted, Madam, becauſe I'm not the Lover you expected?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What Lover! be witneſs Heaven —

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: That thou art falſe, falſe as the inſatiate Seas, that ſmiling tempt the vain Adventurer, whom flattering, far from any ſaving there, ſwell their falſe Waves to a deſtructive Storm.

sp.speaker: Mir:
sp.p: Why all this mighty Rage? — Becauſe I diſappointed you to Night?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: No, by Heaven, I dully cou'd have waited for the Hour; have hop'd, and wiſh'd, and languiſh'd out an Age. But, oh Mirtilla! Oh thou perjur'd Fair! — But vaniſh all the ſoftneſs of my Soul, I will be ſatyrial.
sp.l: A Plague, a Torment, to your fickle Sex,
Thoſe ſmiling, ſighing, weeping Hypocrites.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And can you think my Flight is Criminal? becauſe I ſav'd this worthleſs Life— for you—

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: What Innocence adorns her Tongue, and Eyes! While Hell and Furies gives her Heart its motion, you know not where you are?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Perhaps I do not.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Swear, for thou'rt damn'd already, and by what black Degrees I will unſold: When firſt I ſaw this gay, this glorious Miſchief, tho Nobly born, 'twas hid in mean Obſcurity; the ſhining Viper lay half dead with Poverty, I took it up, and laid it next my Heart, fed it, and call'd its faded Beauties back.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Confeſs'd: And what of this?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Confirm'd you mine, by all the Obligations Profuſeneſs cou'd invent, or Love inſpire.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And yet at your Return you found me marry'd to another.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Death and Hell! that was not yet the worſt: You flatter'd me with ſome Pretence of Penitence; but on the Night, the dear deſtructive Night, you rais'd my Hopes to all diſtracting Love cou'd wiſh— that very Night— Oh let me rave and dye, and never think that Diſappointment o'er!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What, you ſaw me Courted at the Ball, perhaps?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Perhaps I ſaw it in your Chamber too. Breathleſs, and panting with new-acted Joy, the happy Lover lay— Oh Mirtilla!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Nay, if he knows it, I'll deny't no more. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: There is no Honeſty in all thy kind.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Or if there be, thoſe that deal in't are weary of their Trade. But where's the mighty Crime?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: No, I expect thou ſhou'dſt out-face my Eyes, out-ſwear my H • aring, and out-lye my Senſes — The Prince! the Prince! thou faithleſs dear Deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: The Prince! good Heaven! Is all this Heat for him?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Thou own'ſt the Conqueſt then?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: With as much Vanity as thou wouldſt do, if thou hadſt won his Sword: Haſt thou took care wiſely to teach me all the Arts of Life, and doſt thou now upbraid my Induſtry? Look round the World, and thou ſhalt ſee, Lejere, Ambition ſtill ſupplies the Place of Love The wornout Lady, that can ſerve your Intereſt, you ſwear has Beauties that out-charms Fifteen; and for the Vanity of Quality, you feign and languiſh, lye, proteſt, and flatter— All Things in Nature Cheat, or elſe are Cheated.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Well ſaid; take off thy Veil, and ſhew the Jilt.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: You never knew a Woman thrive ſo well by real Love, as by Diſſimulation: This has a Thouſand Arts and Tricks to conquer; appears in any Shape, in any Humour; can laugh or weep, be coy or play, by turns, as ſuits the Lover beſt, while ſimple Love has only one Road of Sighs and Softneſs; theſe to Lejere are due: But all my Charms, and Arts of gay Diſſembling, are for the credulous Prince.— Ha — he's here! — and with him the dear Youth that has enſlav'd me, who triumph's o'er the reſt. Aſide.

div.stage: Enter Prince Frederick, Olivia following, •• s Mirtilla, and withdraws.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Ha! Mirtilla, and my Brother here! Oh how I long to ſee that Stranger's Face. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Mirtilla, thou Charmer of Life's dull and redious Hours, how fares thy Heart? Dwells any Pantings there, but thoſe that Love, and his dear Joys create.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Or if there do, you ſhou'd excuſe it now.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: How many Devils reign in beauteous Woman▪

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
My dear Lejere congratulate my Joys; take all my Friendſhip thou — but thou my Soul. Come, come, my Friend, 〈◊〉 retire together; I'll give thee leave to gaze upon my Heaven, and feed on all the Sweets that Friendſhip may: But all the reſt of the v • ſ •
•• o • e is • rine.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Madam Endimion is already here.
〈◊〉
to h • r.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Thou haſt reviv'd me — Let him w • it my 〈◊〉 .

div.stage:
Exit Prince, and Mirtilla; Geo •• e 〈…〉
at the Door
Olivia comes forward.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Spight! Spight, and dire Revenge, ſeize my fo •• l • oul!— Oh that I were a Man, a looſe lewd Man, how eaſily wou • d I rob him of her Heart, and leave him but the ſhadow of Enjoyment.

div.stage: Re-enter George.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Now, my dear Siſter, if thou ever lovedſt me, revenge thy Brother on this perjur'd Woman, and ſnatch her from this gallant Rival's Arms. She loves thee — Diſſemble thou to love again; meet her Advances with an equal Ardour, and when thou haſt wound her up to dalliance, I'll bring the Prince a witneſs of her Shame.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: But what if he ſhou'd kill me—

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I'll take care of that.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Then e'er the morning dawns, you ſhall behold it: She languiſhes to ſee me, and I wait on purpoſe for her Commands.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: As I cou'd wiſh: Be ſure to Act the Lover well. Exit George.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: As well as I can Act it.
That all Mankind are Damn'd, I'm poſitive; at leaſt all Lovers are.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What have we here? the Spark that rally'd me about a Woman at the Ball to Night? Who is it, Sir, you Curſe ſo heartily?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Ha, how Beautiful he is— how many Charms dwell in that lovely Face— (Aſide.) 'Tis you I curſe.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Gad, I thank you for that, you were kinder to Night, when you told me of a fine Woman that was in Love with me.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Why, what have you to do with Woman-kind?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A pretty civil Queſtion; has the Lady that ſent you, a mind to be inform'd?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Or if ſhe had, you're not at leiſure now you are taken up, Sir, with another Beauty. Did not you ſwear, never to ſpeak to Woman-kind, till I had brought her, I told you, ſigh'd for you?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Right, and I have kept my word Religiouſly.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: The Devil you have, witneſs the Joy Mirtilla gave your Soul: Eve • now you were all Tranſport, all Extaſie of Love; by Heaven you had forgot you brought me in, and paſt Triumphant in Mirtilla's Arms, Love in your Heart, and Pleaſure in your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Ay, ſure he miſtakes me for the Amorous Prince, and thus, perhaps, has miſtook me all the Night: I muſt not undeceive him. Aſide.

What e're you ſaw, I have a heart unwounded, a heart that never ſound •• loved, a little ſcratch it got the other day by a Young Beauty in the Ma •• ,
〈◊〉 Name I know not, but I wiſh'd to know it, and dogg'd her Coach, 〈◊〉
•• gh'd a little after her but ſince ne'er ſaw the lovely Viſion.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Sure this was I. (Aſide.) What Livery had ſhe, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: That I took notice of, 'twas Green and Gold — Since that, I tri •• now and then with Love to chaſe away this Image, and that's all.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Ha, now I view him well, 'tis the ſame handſome Fellow that Entertain'd us in the Mall laſt Thurſday.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: C •• e, Sir, 'tis late, pleaſe you to take a Bed with me to Night, where we'll beget a better Underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: A better than you imagine — 'Sdeath, to Bed with him, I tremble at the thought — Sir, I do not love a Bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir, I have lent my Lodgings to a Stranger of Quality. 〈◊〉 I wou'd offer you a ſingle Bed — but for once you may diſpenſe with a Bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I will not put you to that trouble, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Do you deſign to make me your Friend, and uſe me with Ceremony? Who waits there? Enter Footman.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: 'Slife, what ſhall I do? I cou'd even conſent, to prevent his going to Mirtilla — beſides, I have no home to go to—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come, no more Scruples — here— a Night-Gown and a Cap for the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What ſhall I do— I have a little urgent Buſineſs, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: If there be abſolute neceſſity, I'll ſee you to your Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Oh, by no means, Sir. 'Sdeath, whither can I go?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why do you pauſe? Deal freely with me, Sir, I hope you do not take me for a Lover of my own Sex — Come, come, to Bed.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Go you, Sir, I'll ſit and Read by you till Day.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, Sir, de think my Bed's Infectious?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I ſhall betray my Sex in my denyal, and that at laſt I can but do if Neceſſity compel me to't. Aſide.
Go on, Sir, you have ſham'd me. Exit both.

div.stage: Enter Prince and George.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: And thus thou haſt my whole Adventure out, ſhort was the Conqueſt, but the Joys are laſting.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I am glad on't, Sir.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Why do'ſt wear a Cloud upon thy brows, when Love's gay Sunſhine dances in my Eyes? If thou'rt her Lover too, I pity thee; her Solemn Vows breath'd in the height of love, diſarm me thy hopes, if Friendſhip wou'd permit thee.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I do not think it, Sir —

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Not think it, not think that ſhe has ſworn!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Yes, doubtleſs, Sir — ſhe's Prodigal of Vows, and I dare ſwear, by all ſhe's ſworn by, ſhe'll break 'em all: She has leſs Faith than all the fickle Sex, uncertain and more wanton than the Winds, that ſpares no Births of Nature in their wild courſe, from the tall Cedar, to the flowers beneath, but Ruffles, Raviſhes, and Ruines all.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I ſpeak of my Mirtilla.
Why, ſo do I— of yours, of mine, or any man's Mirtilla.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Away, ſhe that with force of Love can ſigh and weep—

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: This very ſhe, has all the while diſſembled: Such Love ſhe deals to every gawdy Coxcomb, how will ſhe practice then upon a Hero?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Away, it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: By all your Friendſhip to me, Sir, 'tis truth.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Wrecks and Torture,— let her have made of me a meet Example, by whom the couzen'd World might have grown wiſe: No matter, then I had been pleas'd, tho' Cullyed — Why haſt thou ruined my Repoſe with Truths that carry more Damnation than a Lye? But Oh— thou at my Friend, and I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Sir, I have done, and humbly ask your Pardon. Offers to go

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay, Lejere, — if ſhe be falſe, thou'rt all the World has left me; and I believe— but canſt thou prove this to me?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Perhaps I may before the Morning's dawn.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Ha, prove it here — here, in this very Houſe!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Ay, here, Sir

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What, in my Lodgings will ſhe receive her Spark— by Heaven, were he the Darling Son of a Monarch, an Empire's Hope, and Joy of all the Fair, he ſhou'd not live to rifle me of Peace, — Come, ſhew me this deſtin'd Victim to my Rage.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: No, my Revenge is only Comical— If you wou'd ſee how Woman can diſſemble, come on, and follow me.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What, diſturb her Reſt! Didſt thou not ſee her fainting with the Fatigues this Night had given her, and begg'd me I wou'd leave her to Repoſe?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Yes, and wonder'd at her Art; and when you begg'd to watch by her Bed-ſide, with what dear Promiſes ſhe put you off; while every word fell feebly from her Tongue, as if 't had been her laſt, ſo very ſick ſhe was — till you were gone — heark — a Door opens — I will obſcure the Lights.

div.stage: Puts away the Lights.
Enter Olivia. They retire a little.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Was ever Maid ſo near to being undone? Oh, Heavens! in Bed with the dear Man I love, ready to be betray'd by every ſigh. George peeps.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p:
'Tis Olivia.
Pater Manage groping.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I left him here— what, by dark? Endimion, young, ha • dſom Sir, where are you? Calls Olivia.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Do you hear that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh, are you here? — Runs againſt Olivia.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Slife, 'tis Manage— how ſhall I eſcape— Aſide.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Come, Sir, my Lady Mirtilla has diſmiſt her troubleſom Lovers, for your more agreeable Company.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Do hear that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Come ſoftly on, Sir, and follow me.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I'm all Obedience —
She cannot Raviſh me, and that's a Comfort. Aſide, going out.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Oh, Lejere — can this be poſſible? Can there be ſuch a Woman?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Follow him, Sir, and ſee—

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: See what! — Be witneſs of her Infamy! Hell! Hell, and all the Fires of Luſt poſſeſs her, when ſhe's ſo old and lewd, all Mankind ſhun her, — I ll be a Coward in my own di • e Revenge, and uſe no manly Mercy.— But oh, I faint, I faint with Rage and Love, which like two meeting Tydes, ſwell into Storms. — Bear me a minute to my Couch within.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: What have I done, now I repent my Raſhneſs.

div.stage: Scene draws off, diſcovers Mirtilla at her Toylet, drest. Enter Manage, leading Olivia in as Endymion, who falls at Mirtilla's feet, whilſt ſhe's there, ſings a Song; ſhe takes him up.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Riſe,— When Lovers are alone they pardon Ceremony — I ſent for you to end the Night with me; ſay — how ſhall we imploy it?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I'll ſigh, and gaze upon your lovely Face.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Nothing but ſigh, and gaze; we ſhall grow dull.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I'll tell you Tales of Love, and ſing you Songs

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Thy Voice, 'tis true, can charm a thouſand ways; but Lovers time their Joys, theſe for the Day, thoſe for the lovely Night And when they would be ſilently in love, have Muſick of ſoft Sighs and gentler Whiſpers.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Oh, Love inſpires all this — What ſhall I do? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Nay, think not becauſe I ſent for you alone, while Night and Silence favour Lovers Stealths, to take advantage of my yielding Heart.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I wou'd to Heaven ſhe were in earneſt now.

div.stage: A Noiſe. Enter Manage.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh, hide your Favourite, Madam — do you hear.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: A jealous Lover only, comes in ſuch a Storm — Dear, to my Heart, whoſe ſafety is my Life. Submit to be conceal'd— but where — Oh heavens, he comes — 'Tis for you I fear— They ſearch for a place.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He comes—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Here, let my Train ſecure you — Till now I never found the right Uſe of long Trains and Farthingals.

div.stage: She kneels, Man. puts her Train over Olivia.
Enter Prince, and George, at the Door.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, you have made theſe Pauſes and Alarms to give her time to Jilt you.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Pray heaven ſhe do — I'd not be undeceiv'd for all the Sun ſurveys. Enter • .

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: My Lord the Prince! now you are kind indeed. Go • s and embrace, him. —hah! what means this Unc •• cern?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I thoug • t 〈◊〉 left you ſick, extreamly ſick.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And are you • g lov'd to find my Health return?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: No, wondrous glad of it. You're mighty Gay, Mirtilla, much in Glory.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Can he who lays his Fortune at my Feet, think me too glorious for his Arms and Eyes?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Fifty to one, the Gypſ • ji • s him yet. Aſide,

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Pray heaven ſhe lyes but handſomly — Aſide.
— for mine Mirtilla. Ha — ha —

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Am I not yours? You cannot doubt my Vows.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: She'll do't, and make me love her anew for her rare dexterity at diſſembling.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I left you wearied, going to your Bed, but find you at your Toylet gayly dreſt • is if ſome Conqueſt you deſign'd e'er morning.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ma •••• , Sir, from the Fire, ſecur'd theſe Trifles: and I was trying ſeveral Dreſſe • on; that this ſlight Beauty that you ſay has charm'd you, might, when yo • ſ •• it next, compleat the Conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: And that thou wilt, if Flattery can do't.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Now, were ſhe guilty, as I am ſure ſhe is not, this ſoftneſs would undo me, and appeaſe me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: You ſeem as if you doubted what I ſay. This while, Oliv. gets off unſ • en. By all the Powers—

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: H •• d, I ſcorn to need an Oath to ſix my Faith: Oh! thou art all Divine and canſt not err Embraces her.
Curs'd be the Tongue that da • es profane thy Vertue, and curs'd the liſtning Fool that dares believe it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: What a poor, wretched, baflled thing is Man, by feebler Woman aw'd and made a Coxcomb!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Durſt any one traduce my Vertue, Sir? and is it poſſible that you could hear it — Then periſh all the Beauties you have flatter'd.

div.stage: Tears her Head-things.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Come to my Arms, thou Charmer of my Soul! and if one ſpark of Jealouſie remain, one of thoſe precious Tears ſhall quench the C • ime — Oh, come and let me lead thee to thy Bed, and breathe new Vows into thy panting Boſom. Leads her off, ſhe looks back on Geo and ſmiles.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Now all the Plagues of injur'd Lovers wreck thee; 'Sdeath, where has ſhe hid Olivia? or how am I deceiv'd? —'Tis Day, and with it new Invention riſe to damn this Woman to the ſin of Shame: Break all the Chains that hold the Princely Youth, and ſink her with her fancy'd Pow'r and Vanity. Exit.

div.stage: Scene changes to Lady Youthly's. Enter Sir Rowland half drest, Lady Blunder in an Undreſs, Lady Youthly in her morning-dreſs, Tereſia and Mr. Twang.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Morrow my Lady Youthly, and thank you for my Nights Lodging — You are as early up as if it had been your Wedding-day.

sp.speaker: L. You.
sp.p: Truly, Sir Rowland, that I intend.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: But where's the Bridegroom, Madam?
how now, Roger, what, no news yet of George?
Alas! none Sir, none, till the Rubbiſh be removed.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Rubbiſh — What—what is George become the Rubbiſh of the World then? Weeps.

sp.speaker: Twang.
sp.p: Why, Man is but duſt, as a man may ſay, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. Blun.
sp.p: But are you ſure, Roger, my Jewel, my Sir Moggy eſcap'd.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: The Watch drew him out of the Cellar-window, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. You.
sp.p: How Mr. Twang, the Young Gentleman burnt — Oh —

div.stage: falls in a Chair.

sp.speaker: Tire.
sp.p: Alas! my Grandmother faints with your ill News—Good Sir Rowland comfort her, and dry your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Burnt, Madam! No, no, only the Houſe fell on him, or ſo —

div.stage: Feigns Chearfulneſs, and ſpeaks to Lady Youthly.

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: How! the Houſe fell on him— Oh!

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, that's all; why, the young Rogue has a Back like an Elephant— 'twill bear a Caſtle, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: Alas, good Man: What a Mercy 'tis, Mr. Twang, to have a Back like an Elephant!

sp.speaker: La. Blun.
sp.p: Of what wonderful Uſe it is upon Occaſion —

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Ay—but—but I ſhall never ſee him more, Back nor Breaſt. Weeps.

sp.speaker: Twang.
sp.p: Good Sir, diſcomfort not my Lady — Conſider man's a flower —

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Ay, but George was ſuch a Flower! He was, Mr. Twang, he was the very Pink of Prentices. Ah! what a rare Rampant Lord Mayor he wou'd have made? And what a Swinging Sheriff — Cries.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: What, cry, ſo near your Wedding-day, Sir Rowland?

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Well, if he be gone — Peace be with him; and 'Ifaks, Sweetheart, we'll Marry, and beget new Sons and Daughters— but— but— I ſhall ne'er beget another George. Cries.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: This is but a ſcurvy Tune for your Hymenical Song, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Alas! Mrs. Tereſia, my Inſtrument is untun'd, and good for nothing now but to be hung upon the Willows.
Cry within. Murder, Murder, Murder. Enter Footman.

div.stage: Sir Merlin his Sword drawn, and Sir Morgan.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: What's here, my Rogue?

sp.speaker: Twang.
sp.p: What's the matter, Gentlemen, that ye enter the Houſe in this Hoſtile manner?

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: What, Mr. Twang, de ſee!

sp.speaker: Sir Mer.
sp.p: Ay, ay — ſtand by Divinity — and know, that we, the Pillars of the Nation, are come, de ſee — to Raviſh.

sp.speaker: La. Blun.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Sir Morgan. Embraces him.

sp.speaker: Sir Merg.
sp.p: I do not intend to Raviſh, like a Jew, in my own Tribe—

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: What ſay they, Mr. Twang, Raviſh? Oh, ſave my Honour— lead me to my Bed-Chamber, where if they dare venture to come, they come upon their Peril. Twang leads her out. Sir Morgan goes to Tereſia.

sp.speaker: Sir Mer.
sp.p: Old Fellow, do'ſt hear? Sir Pandarus of Troy, deliver me my Creſida, de ſee, peaceably, or I am reſolved to be • r her off Vi & Armis.

sp.speaker: La Blun.
sp.p: Sweet Nephew, retire, we are juſt upon making your Peace.

sp.speaker: Sir Mer.
sp.p: Ha— Old Queen Gwiniver, without her Ruff on? —

div.stage: Sir Merlin takes hold of her to bear her off; ſhe cries out: Sir Rowland draws upon him. As they are going to Fight, Enter George.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Is there a man in Nature's Race ſo vile, dares lift a guilty Hand againſt his Father?

sp.speaker: Sir Mer.
sp.p: Father me no Fathers; I fight for Tereſia, my Lawfully begotten Spouſe.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: That I once call'd you Brother, ſaves your Life; therefore reſign your Sword here at his Reverend Feet.

sp.speaker: Sir Mer.
sp.p: Sirrah; you lye, Sirrah —

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: There, drag away this Brute. Diſarms him. To the Footman.

sp.speaker: Sir Mer.
sp.p: Rogues, Dogs, bring Mrs. Tereſia along with you.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: Sure this is my fine Fellow — and yet the very ſame that's to be marry'd to my Grandmother; nor can that City Habit hide the Gentleman,

div.stage: George ſpeaks this while with his Father, who embraces him.

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: Burnt, ſay you, Mrs. Tereſia de ſee — my Lady Mirtilla burnt! Nay then, 'tis time to go ſleep, get ſober, and Marry again. Goes out.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Enough, my Boy, enough; thou deſerv'ſt my whole Eſtate, and thou ſhalt have it, Boy — This day thou ſhalt Marry the Widow, and I her Grand-child. I'll to my Lawyers, and ſettle all upon thee inſtantly —

div.stage: Goes out.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: How! Marry to day — Old Gentleman, you muſt be couzen'd, and Faith, that goes againſt my Conſcience — Ha, the Fair, the Young Tereſia there — When a man's bent upon Wickedneſs, the Devil never wants an Opportunity to preſent him with, that ſhe ſhou'd be in my way now— Fair Creature, are you reſolv'd to be my Mother-in-law?

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: As ſure as you to be my Grandfather, Sir — And ſee— the News of your being come, has rais'd my Grandmother.

div.stage: Enter Lettice and Lady Youthly.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: A Pox upon her, her Ghoſt had been leſs frightful.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: I cou'd have ſpar'd her now too; but ſee ſhe advances as ſwift as Time.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: And as old: What ſhall I do? I dye to ſpeak with you —

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: Where— where's this Young Welcome Gentleman — Oh, are you here, Sir — She ſees him not, but runs upon him.
Lettice, take Tereſia, and get you to your Chamber, ſhe has her Trinkets to get ready againſt the Wedding anon, for we'll make but one work of both.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: Ay, 'twill ſave Charges, Madam —

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: Ay, ay, get you gone, Lovers ſometimes wou'd be private.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Heark ye — leave me not to her mercy, by Love, if you do, I'll follow you to your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: Leave you! no, hang me if I'do, till I have told you a piece of my mind, for I find there's no dallying.

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I have finiſh'd the Great Work.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I wiſh you had — Tereſia, once you made me hope you did not hate me.

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: What ſays he, Tereſia?

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: He ſays, he hopes you do not hate him, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: No, by my Troth, Sir; I feel ſomething for you, I have not felt before.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Not theſe Threeſcore Years, I dare ſwear — You have too much Wit, Tereſia, to have been only pleas'd with the Embroider'd Coat, and Gawdy Plume, where ſtill the man's the ſame.

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: What ſays he, Embroider'd Coat and Plume?

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: He hopes your Ladyſhip likes him ne'er the worſe, for being without thoſe Fopperies.

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: Marry do I not, I love not this over-finery in a Husband; thoſe Fellows that Dreſs, think ſo well of themſelves, they never mind their Wives.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Are you ſo dull, Tereſia, not to ſee, this Habit was put on, only to get an Opportunity to tell you my Paſſion?

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: Tell me of his Paſſion! was it ſo, alas, good Young Man — Well, well, I'll defer your Joys no longer, this Night ſhall make you happy. Mr. Twang ſhall join us, Sir.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: A bleſſed hearing — You ſee, Charming Maid, how very ſhore a ſpace there is between this and the haſt'ning hour; ſtand not on Virgin Niceties, but anſwer me, our time admits of no Conſideration.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: I have not been this Four and Twenty hours a Lover, to need Conſidering; as ſoon as you had my Heart, you had my Conſent, and that was the firſt moment I ſaw you at the Baſſet-Table.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Ha! at the Baſſet-Table?

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: Yes, I was the frank Youth that lent you Money — but no more— your Time and Place.

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: What are you prating to him there?

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: He doubts your Love, Madam, and I'm confirming it.

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: Alas, good Gentleman! — anon I'll convince him — for in the Ev'ning, Sir, the Prieſt ſhall make us one.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, I cou'd wiſh 'twere not ſo long defer'd, for ſure I love you like a ſighing Swain, and as a Proof of it, I have here prepar'd an Emblem of my Love in a Dance of Country Lovers, where Paſſion is ſincere.

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: Good-lack-a-day, indeed you're ſo obliging: But pray let us have the Dance. Dance.

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: Very pretty indeed. Come, good Gentleman, don't droop, don't droop; come, hold up your Head — you may be allowed one Kiſs beforehand.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: (Kiſſes her.) Oh, what a Peſtilential Blaſt was there? Aſide.

sp.speaker: La. You.
sp.p: Come, come, Tereſia, come with me.

sp.speaker: Geo. to Tereſia.
sp.p: I'll ſend a Chair to your Back-Gate anon, that ſhall wait you on the Field-ſide, and bring you whither I ſhall appoint. Get Ready inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: And if I fail, may I be eternally damn'd to the Embraces of Old Age. Exeunt all but George.

lg.l: Mirtilla, thus thy Scorn I will out-brave,
And let my Father the kind Cheat forgive,
If I with dexterous Charitable care
Eaſe him of Burthens he wants ſtrength to bear. Ex •• .

div.head: SCENE the Firſt.
div.stage: Enter Welborn dreſſing himſelf; to him, a Footman with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: PRethee what became of the Spark that lay with me laſt night?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I know not, Sir, he 'roſe before day— What Letter's this, Sir? It lay upon your Toylet. Gives Welborn a Letter.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: To the dear Man whoſe Name I would be glad to Reads. know—Hum'— a Woman's Hand — Opens it.
The Lady you ſaw laſt Thurſday in the Mall, you had in Bed with you laſt Night. Adieu.
Oh! dull Divinity of Love! that by no Inſtinct, no ſympathizing Pains or Pleaſure, could inſtruct my Senſe, how near I was to Happineſs!
—Lejere, behold me here the moſt unlucky Fellow breathing. Thou know'ſt I told thee how I was in love with a young Woman in the Mall: And this very Night, I had this very Woman in my Arms.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Is this your ill Luck, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, all the while I took her for a Man: But, finding me aſleep, ſhe ſoftly 'roſe; and, by a Light yet burning in my Chamber, ſhe writ this Billet, and left it on my Table. Gives it George, he reads it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: By all that Good, Olivia! — And were you very Honeſt, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: To my eternal Shame, as chaſt as Ice.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: What will you ſay now, Charles, if I bring this Woman to you again?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Canſt thou? Oh, let me kiſs thy Lips away.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: For all her Frollick, Charles, ſhe's very honeſt, a Fortune, and of Quality — and were't not for Olivia, thou ſhouldſt marry her.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Olivia I ne'er ſaw, and now 'twill be too late.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Nay then, Sir, I muſt fight in her Defence.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You fight in her defence! Why, doſt thou love her? — By all that's Good, I will reſign her to thee.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You ſhall not, Sir; and know ſhe is my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Olivia thy Siſter! —

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Ask no more Queſtions, but defend your ſelf, if you refuſe to marry her; for her Honour's mine.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Were ſhe an Angel, I muſt love this Woman.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Then thou ſhalt have her— Haſt, and get a Licence — no more — truſt my Friendſhip— Go. Exit Welborn.
Olivia, where did you lie laſt Night? — Nay do not bluſh, for you may yet be Vertuous.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Virtuous! Not the young Roſes in the bud ſecur'd, nor breaking Morn, ungaz'd at by the Sun; nor falling Snow, has more of Purity.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I do believe you; but your dangerous Frolicks will make the World talk ſhamefully.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Let him talk on, I will not humour Fools.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: No more — here's Manage— Contrive an Aſſignation with Mirtilla; but do not hide again where none may find you. This done, I'll tell you more, and make you happy. How now, Manage, is the Prince ſtirring?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He's in his dreſſing Room, Sir, — This from my Lady, Sir.

div.stage: Slides the Letter into Olivia's hand as ſhe paſſes out.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: What have you there, Olivia? Takes the Billet.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: An Aſſignation from your perjur'd Miſtriſs, Sir.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: 'Tis well—You muſt obey the Summons. And wind her up to all the height of Love; then let her looſe to Shame. I'll bring her Lover in the height of Dalliance, who, when he ſees her Perſidy, will hate her.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: And then the lovely Man ſtands fair for me. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Go write an Anſwer back— and wait her hour. Exeunt ſeverally.

div.stage: SCENE, the Second. The Dreſſing-Room. Diſcovers the Prince at his Toylet, dreſſing. Muſick and a Song. Enter Lejere; waits till the Song is ended. The Prince ſees him, comes to him with Joy, and falls about his Neck.

lg.l: AH, Charmion! ſhroud thoſe killing Eyes,
That dart th' Extreams of Pleaſure,
Elſe Celadon, tho' favour'd, dies
As well as him that you deſpiſe,
Tho' with this diff'rent meaſure:
While ling'ring Pains drag on his Fate,
Diſpatch is all th' Advantage of my State;
For, ah! you kill with Love, as well as Hate.
Abate thy Luxury of Charms,
And only Part diſcover;
Your Tongue, as well as Eyes, had Arms
To give a Thouſand fatal Harms
To the poor liſtening Lover:
Thy Beams, Glory's Veil'd ſhou'd be,
And like the Front of Heav'n, unſeen, paſs by;
For to behold 'em, in full force, we dye.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Lydia, Oh! I faint, I dye with thy Beauty's Luxury! By heaven, I'm all Rapture, Love, and Joy: Such a dear Night, Lejere! — Poets may fancy preſſing Goddeſſes, on downy Beds of Clouds— But oh, Lejere! — Thoſe Gods were never half ſo bleſt as I!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: What pity 'twere to wake you from this Dream.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: It is not in the Power of Time nor Age: For even then Mirtilla will have Charms! Oh, how ſhe ſpeaks! how well ſhe'll grace a Story

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: How gay her Wit! how movingly ſhe writes!

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I do believe ſhe do's. A little ſeriouſly.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Would it diſpleaſe you, ſhould you ſee a Billet from her?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: That's as it were directed. Gravely.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You would not credit what you ſaw laſt night.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Nor wou'd have loſt that Night for all the Treaſure the vaſt Ocean hid •• .

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I wou'd not have a Man ſo good, and great, be made a Woman's P • operty—There, Sir. Gives him the Billet.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I'll not believe it her's; there are a thouſand ways to ruin Innocence; if ſhe be falſe— ſhe's damn'd. Confirm me, and of courſe I ſhall deſpiſe her. You cure me, when you ſhew her worth my Scorn.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Will you be rul'd then, and believe it Friendſhip in me?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Give her, by Abſence, but an Opportunity; feign ſome Excuſe to leave the Town to day.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: See where ſhe comes— Enter Mirtilla.

Adorn'd with all the beauteous Wonders of her Sex. The Gods of Love are playing in her Eyes, and give us Wounds from ev'ry graceful Motion? Ah, my Mirtilla! how ſhall I ſupport the Abſence of a many coming Hours, that languiſh, being from thee but a moment?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I hope, my Lord, Fate is not ſo unkind, to let me live without you many Hours.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Can all this be diſſembl'd? Aſide to George.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: How much more have I heard? yet all was falſe.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I muſt this Day— this tedious live-long Day, be abſent from thy ſight — but ſhall be back i'th'Evening: I'll leave Lejere to wait on your Commands.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Lejere ſhall ever, Sir, be dear to me —
But I'll retire, and ſigh till your Return— That World affords no Pleaſure where you are not.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Do you hear that, Sir? Aſide to George.
Till Night, thou deareſt Bleſſing of my Life — Adieu.

div.stage: Mirtilla going out, pulls Lejere by the Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Thou little, miſchievous, informing Thing, how vainly haſt thou laviſh'd out Invention! Smiling. Exit.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: By Heaven, methinks 'twere Sin but to ſuſpect her.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Think ſo; I'll trouble your Repoſe no more: I've done my Duty, and I wou'd not ſee you made a—

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Property— Ha— A loath'd convenient Tool — A Woman's Implement— S'death! ſhe that off— Looſe to the naſty Love of every Tool, that will be Flatter'd, Cozen'd, Jilted, Cuckolded— No more— I will, unſeen, convey my ſelf into the Cloſet in my Dreſſing-Room; 'tis near her Bed— And if I find her Wanton.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: If you find her— The Youth is waiting now that ſhall convince you.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Where?— Oh ſet the happy Slave but in my View, and—

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: No faith, Sir, be convinc'd before you ſtrike, for fear ſhe jilt you out of Senſe and Reaſon—

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Come to my Cloſet, from thence we may obſerve all that paſſes in her Chamber; from whence I'll break upon the perjur'd Fair, like Thunder from a Cloud, and more deſtructive. Exeunt.

div.stage: Seene diſcovers Mirtilla and Manage.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Is the Prince gone?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Then bring Endimion to me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Madam, I wiſh you'd think no more of him; for I foreſee, that this Amour muſt Ruine you. Remember you have left a Husband for the Prince.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: A Husband, my Drudge, to toil for me, and ſave me the Expence of careful Thoughts: My Cloak, my Led-Horſe, for Neceſſity to fill my Train— no more— but Endimion waits. Exit Manage.

—There is a native Generoſity in me, that checks my Inconſtancy to this great Man; yet I have ſo much Woman in my Soul, cannot pain my ſelf to do him Juſtice— A new deſire of humouring my Wiſh, ſways all my Intereſt, and controuls all my Honour. Why ſhould I loſe a Pleaſure for a Promiſe, ſince Time, that gives our Youth ſo ſhort a Date, may well excuſe our needful Perjury. Enter Manage, and Olivia, ſhe runs and Embraces him. —Let the young baſhful Maid, unskill'd in Love, deny the preſſing Swain.
Let wither'd Age who fondly dreams of Virtue, loſe the dear Opportunities of Life.
The coming Hours preſent themſelves to us; and are too nice, not to be ſnatch'd when offer'd.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: So haſty this diſarms me of Excuſe. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Why are thy Eyes bent down? Why doſt thou pauſe?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: So hot!— I muſt prepare to ſhew my Sex's Evidence, if nothing elſe will do. Unbuttons her Coat.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What not a Word!
Advance thou baſhful Youth — Love in thy Eyes, and Coward in thy Heart! The one all Fire, the other too much Ice.

div.stage: Prince, and George, looking out.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Yet ſtay me, my Lejere, from my haſty Vengeance.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, how are you miſtaken! 'Tis not Coldneſs in me— but—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What? Baſhfulneſs!
Oh Love will lend thee Courage.
This Trembling is the ſoft Effects of it.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Oh how vilely ſhe's miſtaken!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Come to my Bed, and preſs the Roſes down; and lend more ſweetneſs to 'em than they bring.

div.stage: She leading him to her Bed. The Prince enters, with Lejere, holding his Sword in hand, he takes hold of Olivia.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Love— thus I fling thy gaudy Fetters off, and am no more a Slave to faithleſs Beauty.

div.stage: The Prince helding Olivia by the Boſom of her Coat, her Breaſt appears to Mirtilla.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ha! what do I ſee?— Two Female riſing Breaſts. By Heav'n a Woman.— Oh fortunate Miſchance.

div.stage: This while George is arguing with the Prince, not to hurt Olivia.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: No I will not hurt thee, ceaſe thy trembling.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, 'twere Sin to hurt the lovely Youth.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: No, Madam, ſince I have taken back my Heart, I can preſent you with another Lover. Gives Olivia to her

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ha! another Lover!— What means my Prince?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Eternally to leave you to your Frailty.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Can you ſo eaſily cancel all your Vows?
Then kill me at your Feet I do implore it. Kneels and Weeps.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Away, I do forgive Thee, wretched Woman — But yet be gone— leaſt Love and Rage return, and I ſhould kill you yet with your young Darling.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Whom mean you, Sir, this lovely Maid?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Maid!— What means ſhe? Sure ſhe cannot know me.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Talk on, falſe Woman! till thou haſt perſwaded my Eyes and Ears out of their native Faculties, I ſcorn to credit other Evidences.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Try 'em once more, and then repent, and dye.

div.stage: Opens Olivia's Boſom, ſhews her Breaſts.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Ha— by Heav'n a Woman!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: You that wou'd ſmile at my ſuppos'd undoing, preſent your ſelf no more before my Eyes 'Twas to perplex you that I feign'd this Paſſion.
I ſaw you had your Spies to watch for Miſchief, To George.
And poiſon all my Happineſs with the Prince.—

And ſince I'm thought ſo Criminal, I'll take an everlaſting Leave of you To the Prince. When I am dead, may ſhe you honour next repay your Tenderneſs as I have done— But may ſhe never meet my wretched Fate. She ſnatches Olivia's Sword out.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Hold, thou moſt valu'd Treaſure of the World, or turn the pointed Weapon to my heart.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: No, I'm falſe; unworthy of your Love.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Yes, by Heav'n. But thou haſt Jilted him ſo handſomly, thou'ſt vanquiſh'd all my Rage.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes. I am falſe; falſe to this Gallant Man. To George.
Falſe to my Husband, to my Sexes Fame; for you more Charming, I alas, am perjur'd.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Lejere! have I then injur'd thee?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: This is the Fatal Beauty, Sir, for whom ſo often you have ſeen me languiſh.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Ah! woud'ſt thou ſee me on a Precipice, and not prevent my Danger?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: To mightier Friendſhip I cou'd all ſurrender, and ſilently have born her Perjuries; but thoſe to you, awaken'd all my Rage; but ſhe has out-trick'd me, and I beg her Pardon— And to ſecure her yours, have lov'd anew, and beg Protection in your Lodgings, Sir, for a young Maid whom I deſign to marry.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Command my Life, my Fortune, and my Sword, for the unwilling Injury I have done thee— And is this the charming perjur'd Fair, Mirtilla?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: It is, Sir.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Since it is poſſible that you cou'd ceaſe to love this Gallant Man, whom I have heard with ſo much tender Paſſion tell your Loves, what ſacred Vows had paſt, and what Endearments, how can I hope from thee a laſting Faith?— Yet on the Oaths that thou haſt ſworn to me— by all thy Hopes of Pardon for thy Perjuries, to eaſe my panting Heart— once ſpeak the Truth— Didſt thou not take this Woman for a Man?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I did— and were ſhe ſo, I wou'd with Pride own all the Vows I've broke.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Why this is fair— and tho' I buy this Knowledge at the vaſt Price of all my Repoſe; yet I muſt own, 'tis a better Bargain then chaff'ring of a Heart for feign'd Embraces— Thou haſt undone me— yet muſt have my Friendſhip; and 'twill be ſtill ſome Eaſe in this Extream, to ſee thee yet repent, and love Lejere.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: No, Sir, this Beauty muſt be firſt declining, to make me take up with a former Lover.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: No, Sir, I have diſpos'd my Heart another way; and the firſt knowledge of her Falſhood cur'd me: Her Marriage I forgave— that thing of form — But never cou'd her Fondneſs to this Youth.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Who's this Lady, Sir, whoſe Pardon I muſt beg?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: My Siſter, Sir, who I diſguis'd on purpoſe to be a Guard to this ſuſpected Fair One.

div.stage: Enter Welborn.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Ha! ſhe's there!
Now every Feature points me out my Conquereſs. — Nay ſtart not— I have found Thee, thou malicious Charmer, to bring me ſo near to Bliſs, and not afford me one kind hint.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: And are not you a very dull Fellow, that lov'd and long'd, and had the Maid ſo near you, and yet needed a Hint.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Nay, if you conceal'd your precious Talent, how ſhou'd it profit any Body?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Conceal'd it?— No, Faith, I made a very fair Tender; but you refus'd it, as not being Currant Coin.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: But if you moſt feloniouſly, and unlawfully deface our Sovereign's Image, ſo as it may be as ſoon taken for the Grand Signior's, I may ſuſpect the Metal too.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What ſay you if I tender it before theſe lawful Witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I'll take it for good Payment— I Charles Wellborn—

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Ha, Welborn! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Take thee— whom?— Gad if the Parſon of the Pariſh knew your Name no better than I— 'twill be but a blind Bargain.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Olivia, Marteen—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My deſtin'd Wife?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: The very ſame: Have you the Parſon ready?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He waits in my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Madam, I beg you'll lend me ſomething more becoming my Sex.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Manage will furniſh you from my Wardrobe. Exit Olivia.

div.stage: Enter Tereſia.

sp.speaker: Geo
sp.p: And ſee my good Genius appears too.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: See, Sir, I am reſolv'd to be welcome to your Arms; look here are the Writings of the Eſtate my Grandfather left me, and here's Three thouſand Pound my Grandmother has ſettl'd on me, upon her Marriage with you.

div.stage: Gives him the Writings.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: And here's my Father's Eſtate ſettled on me — Come let's put them together— and go in, and let the Parſon do as much for us.

div.stage: Puts 'em in her Caſe.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: But have you very well conſidered this Matter?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Tereſia, we'll do like moſt Couples, marry firſt, and conſider afterwards— Leads her in

div.stage: Enter a Footman.

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: Sir, Here's Sir Merlin, with a Lady mask'd, wou'd ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Carry 'em into the Dining-Room, I'll wait on 'em anon.

div.stage: Exeunt Omnes.
SCENE, my Lady Youthly's. Diſcovers Her, and Lettice dreſſing her.

sp.speaker: L. You.
sp.p: Hold the Glaſs higher, Lettice; Is not this Tour too brown? — Methinks it does not give a youthful Ayre to my Face.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: That's not in Nature.

sp.speaker: L. You.
sp.p: Like Nature! Ay, but Nature's ſelf wants Art, nor does this Fontange ſuit with my Complexion— Put on a little more Red, Lettice, on my Cheeks, and Lips. She does ſo.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Ay, for they are but a little too much upon the Coventry Blue — This Tour muſt come more forward, Madam, to hide the Wrinkles at the corners of your Eyes — Pulls it.

sp.speaker: L. You.
sp.p: Ay, Lettice, but there are others, that neither Tours, nor Paint, nor Patches will hide, I fe • r — Yet altogether, Lettice —

div.stage: Puts on her Spectacles, and looks in the Glaſs.
Enter Sir Rowland.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: What, no Bride yet, nor Bridegroom!

sp.speaker: L. You.
sp.p: Ay, what can be the Meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: But Tereſia, Madam, where can ſhe be gadding?

sp.speaker: L. You.
sp.p: Why Lettice tells me, She went to buy ſome Trifles to adorn her this. Night — Her Governante is with her, and my Steward.
Twang, Alas, what pity 'tis; the Supper is quite ſpoil'd, and no Bridegroom come!

div.stage: (A Noiſe of Hallowing without, and Muſick.) Enter Lady Blunder.

sp.speaker: L. Blun.
sp.p: Bleſs us! Here's a whole Regiment of Liveries, Coaches, and Flambeau's, at the Door! The Fops of the Town have heard of a Wedding, and are come in Maſquerade.

div.stage: Enter Muſick playing; after them, Prince Frederick leading Mirtilla, George leading Tereſia; Sir Merlin, Diana, Mrs. Manage, Brittoon, Pages, and Footmen, all in Maſquerade. Sir Morgan comes in, all in Mourning; Welborn, and Olivia.

sp.speaker: Sir Mer.
sp.p: Hearing of a high Wedding, Sir, we made bold (as the Saying is) to give you Joy. Sir, Are not you the Bridegroom?

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: Where's your Bride, Sir? Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Mer.
sp.p: Ay, ay, where's your Bride?

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: What's that to you, Sir, Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: Sir Mir.
sp.p: Hum— How the Devil came he to know me now? — Is this Reverend Gentlewoman your Lady, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Ounds, they come to mock us! — Hark ye, hark ye Tawdrums, if you are Men, ſhew your Faces; if Apes, play over your Monkey-Tricks, and be gone, d'ye hear? — We are not at leiſure for Fooling.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Be but at leiſure, Sir, to pardon (George kneels) this one Diſobedience of my Life, and all the reſt I'll dedicate to pleaſe and humour you. Sir, I am marry'd. Pulls off his Mask.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: What the Devil's that to me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Do not you know me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: No, Sir, nor don't care to know any ſuch ſlaunting Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Look on me, Sir. Looks on him, knows him, goes away, and returns.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Hum, hum, hum!—

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: It is your Son, Sir, your darling Son, who has ſav'd your Life from Inſolence?

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Hum — Tereſia!

sp.speaker: L. You.
sp.p: How, Tereſia! what robb'd me of my intended Husband? Oh undone! undone! Falls into a Chair.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: And haſt thou after all, ſerved me ſuch a Rogne's Trick, thou ungracious Varlet? What Cuckold thine own Father!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Oh do not frown, I canno • bear your Anger! Here will I hang for ever till you Pardon me. Claſps his Knees.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Look — look — now cannot I be angry with the good-natur'd young Rogue Weeps.
Well George — But hark ye, Sirrah, this is a damn'd Trick of yours.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Sir, I found my Youth was fitter for her than your Age, and you'll be as fond of a Grand-Child of my begetting, as you would of a Son of another Man's, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Thour't in the Right on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Mer.
sp.p: Ha! Is Monſieur Lejere then my Brother George?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Sir, Here's another Couple wants your Pardon; my Brother Merlin, and my Lady Diana.

sp.speaker: La. Blun.
sp.p: Diana! what Sir Harry Modiſh's Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Yes, he pawn'd me at the Baſſet-Table; and, in Revenge, I reſolv'd to marry the next Man of Fortune I met with.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: The Fool had more Wit then I thought he had; for which I'll give him a Thouſand Pound a Year.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I humbly thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Pray, Melancholy Sir, who are you in Mourning for?

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: Alas! Madam, for a Perſon of Quality that was my Wife; but reſt her Soul, ſhe's burnt Weeps.
And I ſhall never ſee any thing again like her.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: No! What think you of this Face, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: As Gad ſhall ſa' me, as like as if the ſame.

sp.speaker: La. Blun.
sp.p: In troth, and ſo ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: 'Tis true, ſhe was once your Wife; but I have preſerv'd her from the Flames, and I have moſt Right to her.

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: That's a hard Caſe, Sir, that a Man muſt loſe his Wife, becauſe another has more Right to her than himſelf; Is that Law, Sir?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Lover's Law, Sir.

sp.speaker: La. Blun.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Son, 'tis the Faſhion to marry one Week, and ſeparate the next: I'll ſet you a Preſident for it my ſelf.

div.stage: In this time Welborn kneels with Olivia; Sir Rowland takes 'em up, and kiſſes 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: Nay, if it be the Faſhion, I'll e'en into the Country, and be merry with my Tenants, and Hawk, and Hunt, and Horſe-match.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: But now, Sir, I'll reſign my Right to you, and content my ſelf with the Honour to have preſerv'd her from the Fire.

div.stage: Prince delivers Mirtilla to Sir Morgan, who receives her.

sp.speaker: Sir Morg.
sp.p: As gad ſhall ſa'me, Sir, you're a civil Perſon; and now I find you can endure a Woman, Sir, I'll give you leave to viſit her.

sp.speaker: Sir Row.
sp.p: Well, ſince we're all agreed, and that the Fiddles are here, adsnigs we'll have a Dance, Sweet-heart, tho' thou haſt out-witted me.

div.stage: Takes Tereſia, George takes Lady Youthly, &c. After the Dance, Lady Youthly weeps.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: VVhat, weeping yet? Here, Mr. Twang, take the Lady to your Care; in theſe Caſes, there's nothing like the Conſolation of your young Chaplain.
sp.l: The Widow, with young Jointure, and old Face,
Affected Mien, and Amorous Grimace,
Ʋſes to fall to th' younger Brother's ſhare;
But I by Fortune, and Induſtrious Care,
Have get one that's Rich, Witty, Young, and Fair.
